subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I don t think I have conveyed my sentiment clearly, so I apologize. I don t mean for QS to be as precise as IPA. Nor do I mean to say that we should change
messageBody:
pgabhart wrote:
>
>
> Paul:
>
> What I have seen written here or on the Shavian group -- I forget where
> -- is that an alphabet used for communication among lay people untrained
> in linguistics and phonetics does not require, nor is it particularly
> useful for it to have, the precision which the IPA was designed for.
> The average writer is trying to communicate to another person at a
> distance, not think about whether an English "p" is aspirated or not.
>
> Thus, I can be perfectly consistent with the manner in which I use QS
> vowels in my writing, and someone from another speech community such as
> Australia or Ireland, may write the same words with the same QS vowels
> that I used and be perfectly consistent in their writing, but the
> corresponding vowels are not pronounced exactly the same by myself and
> the other two writers. That does not render QS useless or a toy. In
> fact, it renders it more useful because it has flexibility which the IPA
> cannot have and enables it to work for, essentially, all English speakers.
>

I don't think I have conveyed my sentiment clearly, so I apologize. I
don't mean for QS to be as precise as IPA. Nor do I mean to say that we
should change the way that words are spelled in different contexts, as a
true linguistic rendering would require. We are in full agreement when
we say that it does not matter if the "p" is apirated or not.

What I am prosing is an accurate way to describe words in their ideal
context, which I guess usually mean alone. Let's take the letter "On,"
#35. This vowel is used in the word ox, which dictionary.com lists the
IPA describes the vowel in this word as:

ɒ

This is the the mouth being fully open and the pronounced at the back of
the mouth with rounded lips. This should be exactly as all of us who
understand IPA think about this vowel. (Let me address how those without
linguistic knowledge will think of this below.) There should be no room
for ambiguity. I strongly advocate that we set this as a standard,
perhaps in a FAQ for example.

I feel the advantages of describing letter in IPA is thus:

1. We give QS a precision. For example, we would allow QS to represent
dialects accurately. When an expert in QS writes dialect, say in a
story, we can know exactly what he means.

2. We avoid the ambiguity that plagues the manual right now and gives
both beginners and experts a head ache. For example, the revised
alphabet gives the narme "On" to letter 34. If you look this up at
dictionary.com, you find that the vowel in this word can be either #33
or #34! So the very example, used in a revised alphabet, once again
creates ambiguity.

If you don't think this is a problem, just read some of the emails that
this thread has generated. It seems many beginners (including myself)
stumble on 32, 33 & 34. It takes us a while to realize that many
dialects don't distinguish between these.

Describing a word in terms of other words is simply circular reasoning
and unhelpful. Let me repeat: the manual is very inadequate in this
respect, as is the shawtwo document. I have had to do a lot of work on
my own to try to work on my own to decipher exactly what is meant by
#32, #33, and #34. I would rather have spent this time working on the
font or on a text.

3. We enable more precise discussion on this issue in the future and
avoid wasting time. Even as I write this, I am still unsure if #34 does
in fact represent the back, open, rounded vowel. It would be nice if
this issue came up again to simply point to a faq. This also allows us
to settle issues in a more precise and less emotional matter. For
example, if a debate arises over the "correct" spelling of a word, we
can look up the the IPA of the word and say "This is the *standarized*
*American* (or British or whatever) way of spelling the word, but your
dialect may differ."

Regarding the layman. It is true that we should never require QS users
to have extensive or even any knowledge of linguistics. But on the one
hand that shouldn't prevent us who do know some linguistics from using
the precision of its terminology. On the other hand, we should take more
care to describe the letters. Simply saying a letter sounds like such
and such a word is inadequate. We could have sound recordings on a web
site. Or, we could say something like "The 'Ah' sound sounds like the
"a" in "father," for Northeastern speakers. Think of saying "ahh" when
you go to the doctor. Your mouth should be fully open (that is why the
doctor has you make this sound!). Many speakers outside the Northeast
region of the US will not pronounce father this way. In this case, you
should use letter #34 instead. Speakers from such and such a region will
hardly ever use this sound..." Of course, we would need even a better
description than this, one that would cover different regions of the
world. And we probably dont' need that much detail for the consanants.

Let me state one very good reason for using the IPA to describe lettes.
Let's say I write a short story that takes place in Boston. I want to
convey the dialect. In traditional orthograpy, I can write words like
"wundaful" for wonderful, and a reader would recognize what I am trying
to convey. That is because there is a standard way in TO, so a non
standard spelling will make the reader see the word as pronounced
differently Now if I write the story in QS, how am I to convey this
dialect? I can write the word using the QS letters as they are described
in the manual, but if QS users are used to using the letters sloppily,
mixing up #32, #33, and #34, then how will they read what I mean? They
will simply think that I am mixing up the letters as they do.

I hope you and others consider my reasons carefully, because I would
like to see more clarity on this issue to avoid confusion in the future,
and I think my suggestions would strengthen QS without making it too
rigid, since users will always be free to spell words however they want.

Paul
